Amazon Q Developer now supports Model Context Protocol (MCP) in IDE plugins like VS Code and JetBrains, allowing developers to integrate external tools for more contextual workflows. This opens the door to more customized, AI-assisted development experiences.
https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/aws-weekly-roundup-aws-reinforce-2025-aws-waf-aws-control-tower-and-more-june-16-2025/

AWS has introduced several services that support the Model Context Protocol (MCP), which is an open protocol for standardizing how AI models securely access external tools, data sources, and APIs.
Currently, AWS offers MCP servers for:
AWS Serverless (AWS Lambda)
Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS)
Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS)
Finch
These MCP servers enhance AI-assisted development by providing AI code assistants with real-time, contextual understanding of AWS services. They incorporate AWS operational best practices, Well-Architected principles, and service-specific optimizations.
Additionally, Amazon Q Developer CLI now supports MCP, allowing developers to leverage a wider range of tools and prompts for richer contextual development workflows. This integration enables Amazon Q to provide more customized responses by orchestrating tasks across native and MCP server-based tools.
AWS is also working on integrating MCP with Amazon Bedrock, which would streamline integration between language models and AWS data services. For AWS customers, MCP represents an opportunity to use existing AWS security mechanisms like IAM for consistent access control and to build composable, scalable AI solutions.
To get started with MCP on AWS, you can explore the aws-labs GitHub repository, which contains installation guides, example configurations, and additional specialized servers.
Sources
